abstract.p: Edmund Lingan letter in response to Anne Midgette's August 6 article notes unedited staging of Faust, Parts 1 and 2 was presented several times by Goetheanium in Dornach, Switzerland, beginning in 1939 (S)

block.p: Peter Stein's unedited production of ''Faust,'' Parts 1 and 2, in Hanover, Germany, is a monumental accomplishment. Peter Stein's unedited production of ''Faust,'' Parts 1 and 2, in Hanover, Germany, is a monumental accomplishment. But in Anne Midgette's article ''Germany's Classic of Classics, All 21 Hours'' [Aug. 6], she writes, ''Asserting that no one has ever presented an unedited staging of the work, Mr. Stein calls his 'Faust' a world premiere.'' It should be noted that uncut versions of ''Faust,'' Parts 1 and 2, have been presented at the Anthroposophical arts center in Dornach, Switzerland, known as the Goetheanum.

The first uncut Dornach production of Goethe's monumental play was performed in 1938 by Marie Steiner's company. According to a 1967 Anthroposophical Society publication, the production lasted almost 23 hours over a series of days. The complete, uncut ''Faust'' was produced at the Goetheanum in 1939, 1947, 1949, 1952, 1959 and 1963.
